explanation:
Agent A is correct. The code invokes memchr and memcmp from <string.h> with lengths derived from caller-provided uri_len and from daemon->unescape_callback, but there is no shown check that these lengths do not exceed the actual allocated sizes of the buffers passed. Concretely:

- memchr(uri, '?', uri_len) will read uri_len bytes from uri; if the original buffer is smaller than uri_len this is an out-of-bounds read.
- uri[uri_len] = 0; writes at offset uri_len, which requires the buffer to have at least uri_len+1 bytes (this is an additional out-of-bounds-write hazard even though it is not a string.h call).
- daemon->unescape_callback returns a new uri_len which is then used in memcmp(uri, connection->rq.url, uri_len). If that returned value exceeds the actual allocated size of either operand (uri or connection->rq.url), memcmp will perform out-of-bounds reads.

MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 prohibits uses of string.h functions that may access beyond object bounds. Because the code does not verify buffer capacities relative to the lengths passed to memchr/memcmp (nor constrain the unescape callback's return), the reported violation is valid. To comply, the code must ensure—by contract or explicit checks—that the lengths passed to these functions do not exceed the allocated sizes of the corresponding buffers.
